WORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No.320 February 1979 SMALL FARMERS AND THE LANDLESS IN SOUTH ASIA The majority of the world's poor are among the 625 million people who reside in the rural areas of Bangladesh, India and Pakistan. The rural poor consist predominantly of (i) small owner and tenant cultivators with opera- tional holdings of less than 5 acres (2 hectares), and (ii) the landless. There are approximately 83 million households with,a population of 410 mil- lion in these categories. This paper attempts to examine the prospects for improved livelihood for these households and the problems faced by them in the three major countries of South Asia. Improving the livelihood of small cultivators depends, in the absence of anv major programs of land redistribution, upon improving their produc- tivity. The availability of abundant family labor and cash scarcity suggests an initial concentration on labor-intensive methods to raise small farmer productivity through improved cultural practices. Further increases in pro- ductivity require multiple cropping, increased use of inputs--water, nutrients, pesticides--and the adoption of high-yielding varieties (HYVs). The paper examines both the prospects and the problems involved in pursuing these strategies. For those with little or no land--the landless, near-landless and mar- ginal farmers--only increasing employment opportunities in rural areas provide any source of hope. There are two sources for such employment growth--on-farm demand for wage labor and non-farm employment in ancillary activities such as poultry, dairying and livestoc and in fisheries, forestry, marketing, trans- portation and processing services in rural areas. The available evidence suggests that both these sources of employment depend upon vigorous agricul- tural growth. In its absence increased reliance has to be placed on rural works programs to provide employment. Although experience shows that such programs had no significant impact on rural employment, a recent experiment-- the Maharashtra Employment Guarantee Scheme in India--provides at least a glimmer of hope. In South Asia the sheer magnitude of the task suggests that rural works programs will make inroads into the employment problem only if accompanied by vigorous agricultural growth.  SMALL FARMERS AND THE LANDLESS IN SOUTH ASIA 1/ SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS I. The Scope of the Problem 1. The majority of the world's poor are among the 625 million people who reside in the rural areas of Bangladesh, India and Pakistan. With between 75 - 90% of their population in rural areas, agriculture is the main occupation of between 60 - 70% of the total labor force in these countries, and accounts for between 40 - 60% of the GDP. 2. Although some studies have purported to show that the real incomes of the rural poor have been declining absolutely or that the proportion of the rural population below an arbitrarily desig- nated "poverty line" has been increasing, or both, the evidence is sketchy and controversial. All that can be said with any certainty is that the absolute numbers of the rural poor have increased in South Asia in the past two decades. 3. Due to the limitations of available data it has been necessary to transform the definition of "poor" in terms of income into a definition based on land cultivated per household. Obviously a correct transfQrmation would take account of the quality of land, the cropping patterns, irrigation, conditions of tenure and other characteristics. However, a cutoff of 5 acres of operated area (2 hectares) serves as an acceptable proxy and is used as a working definition throughout this paper to identify the rural poor. 4. Using this definition the rural poor consist predominantly of (i) small owner and tenant cultivators with operational holdings of less than 5 acres (2 hectares) and (ii) the landless. The estimated numbes of households and population in 1977 in these categories are: Banglade-h India Pakistan Households P Households Popn, Households Popn --- (in millions -- Small Cultivators 6 33 45 213 1 7 Landless 6 37 24 114 1 6 Total 12 70 69 327 2 13 1/ Throughout this paper South Asia is used to refer to Bangladesh, Pakistan and India only.
 - ii - II. Small Farms: Definition and Characteristics 5. Despite the extrerme diversity in South Asia it is possible to define three broad categories of small cultivators: (i) Nedr landless - those with less than one acre (0.4 hectares) of operated area. The present holdings of this group of farmers are too small to provide a subsistence standa-d of living even allowing for productivity increases that ait likely in the future. These households are akin to the landless in their dependence on rural wage incomes as a major source of livelihood. They can also supplement their wage incomes through a variety of on-farm ancillary activities such as dairying and poultry. The near landless account for 31% of the cultivated holdings and 3% of the cultivated area in South Asia. (ii) Marginal Farmers - those with between 1 and 2.5 ackes (0.4 - 1 hectare) of operated area, whose holdings at present levels of productivity are too small to provide an adequate standard of living but whose per capita incomes could be improved substantially by 'future productivitv increases, Nonetheless, wage incomes will remain an important supplement to their faxm incomes. Farming alone will not provide a decent standard of living. Marginal farmers account for 19% of the cultivated holdings and 6% of the cultivated area in South Asia. (iii) Small Farmers - those with between 2.5 and 5 acres (1-2 hectares) of operated area, whose holdings at Present levels of productivity provide a standard of living at the bare margin of subsistence but where future farm productivity increases could definitely provide an adequate standard of living. For these farmers farming alone could provide a decent living, but it will more likely continue to be supplemented by incomes from other sources as they push for higher standards of living. Small farmers account for 19% of the cultivated holdings and 12% of the cultivated area in South Asia. 6. Among the characteristics peculiar to small farmers are (i) a high proportion of land devoted to food crops; (ii) a low proportion of output marketed (a high proportion retained for home consumption); (iii) a more diverse crop portfolio; (iv) greater aversion to risk; (v) a greater scarcity of cash and capital resources; and (vi) more abundant family labor than other larger farms. It is a misconception to view small farmers as inefficient, tradition-bound, unresponsive to economic oppor- tunities or unwi'.ling to adopt new ideas and technologies or to view the small farm sector as unproductive and stagnant. These cha- racteristics are important in assessing the appropriate means to raise small farmer productivity.
 - iii - III. Increasing Small Farmer Productivity: Cropping Practices 7. The availability of abundant family labor and the scarcity of cash among small farms suggest that initially we must concentrate on labor-intensive and cash-saving methods of raising small farmer productivity. This is the concept underlying the extension message in the Training and Visit System developed by Benor and Harrison. Simple management practices beginning with increased plant popula- tions and proper plant spacing,followed by the use of good seeds, seed treatment, proper tilling, weeding and improved seed bed, nursery and land preparation need to be emphasized. 8. Considerable success has been achieved with this system and a careful analysis of the available evidence suggests that (i) yield increases in the range of 10 - 30% on rainfed land and 25 - 50% on irrigated land can be obtained without any increase in any other inputs apart from labor and the knowledqe of these practices; (ii) most ot these practices are adoptea very rapiduy (2 - 3 years) once they are introduced, and (iii) that there are no significant differences between farms of different sizes in the rates of adoption, the number of practices adopted, or the yield increases achieved. All farmers, includinq small farmers, can benefit from the introduction of such simple practices. 9. Althouigh these promising results are based on very recent and limited evidence and experience from a few Indian states (Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, West Bengal and Assam) and suqqest appropriate caution, it is encouraging that these states are among those whose past agricu:Ltural performance has been poor and which have a large number of small cultivated holdings. 10. The ability to replicate these practices over large areas quickly will depend upon how extensive the coverage is of the exist- ing extension systems, how quickly these can be reorganized, and also on the existing accumulation of region-specific research and extension. In this regard it may be easier to extend these practices and realize their benefits more quickly in India than in Bangladesh and Pakistan where research and extension infrastructures arrf less developed. 11. Further yield increases can be obtained by making fuller use of the little land available to small farmers, through multiple cropping. T'here is a need to change the emphasis from increasing yields per unit area to increasing yields per unit area per unit time. This requires the use of land to grow two or even three crops per year, with somewhat less than proportional, but still substantial, increases in small farmer incomes.
 - iv - 12. Although in aggregate the intensity of land use in South Asia seems low (only 10 - 15% of the land under multiple cropping in India and Pakistan and 40% in Bangladesh compared to nearly 90% in Republic of China, cropping intensities are inversely related to farm size. The area multiple-cropped on farms smaller than rive acres ranges from 16 - 27% in India and 30 - 50% in Pakistan, while in Bangladesh it is nearly 60 - 80%--as high as in Republic of China. In India and Pakistan we are talking about the need to get two crops per year on a larger percentage of the area, while in Bangladesh on the other hand we are talking about getting three crops a year, on a larger percentage of the area and on small farms. 13. Doubling the cropping intensity would virtually double faxm incomes as well as farm employment on all farms, with significant benefits for the landless and smallholders who seek seasonal employment on larger holdings. 14. Although increased multiple cropping will be beneficial tc) all farmers as well as the landless, significantly higher croppinnq intensities will not be easy to achieve quickly. This is because increased multiple cropping involves the careful and scientific management of complex croppinq systems in which the timely performance of agricultural operations, tied to the quicker maturity of crops, will have to be complemented by the development of extensive and efficient marketing systems and distribution networks to assure timely access to relevant inputs and services to all, but particularly small farmers. 15. In their order of importance the most necessary (but not sufficient) conditions for increased multiple cropping on small farms are: (i) increased irrigation and better water control; (ii) improved quick-maturing crop varieties; (iii) improved crop management; (iv) increased nutrient use; (v) better insect and disease control; and (vi) more efficient post-harvest technologies.
 IV. Increasing Small Farmer Productivity: Input-Intensive Strategies 16. Further productivity increases-- beyond those obtained by changing simple cropping practices--require additional phvsical inputs such as (i) new seeds; (ii) nutrients and pesticides;(i'i) irrigation, as well as institut:Lonal inputs such as (iv) credit; (v) marketing infrastruc- ture; (vi) research and extension to disseminate knowledge and (vii) management skills. 17. There is considerable evidence that small farmers have adopted the "green-revolution" technologies--high yielding varieties (HYV) and nutrient use--extensively and have benefitted considerably as a result. Although HYVs have been limited mainly to irrigated areas, and HYV wheat has been adopted much more extensively than HYV rice (which has required more location-specific adaptation), small farmers in recent years have matched the performance of large farmers, in terms of (i) percentage of farmers using HYVs, (ii) percentage of sown area under HYVs, and (iii) intensity of nutrient use per hectare.at least in India and Banqladesh. In Pakistan they have generally lagged behind larger farmers but more recently-- since 1974--they have started to adopt these technologies more rapidly. 18. In spite of this rapid adoption small farmers have not realized all their potential gains from increased use of HYVs and nutrients. Additional per hectare yield increases of between 20 - 120% are possible under irrigated conditions depending upon the crop and variety sowna. These represent increases in net incomes of a similar order for small farmers. Under unirrigated conditions the potentials for additional yield increases are extremely low except for a few selected crops. Thus increased irrigation is central to realizing large productivity increases on small farms. 19. The extent to which these potential yield and income increases will be realized on small farms will depend upon (i) small farmer access to the necessary inputs, especially irrigation, (ii) the agrarian structure and conditions of tenancy, and (iii) small farmer control and participation in local institutions. 20. Increased irrigaion is central. Although considerable addi- tional potential for surface and groundwater irrigation exists and is being exploited in South Asia, several institutional and economic problems that hamper the ability of small farmers in obtaining their share of this essential resource will have to be overcome. For sur- face irrigation these include (i) the lack of investable funds to build on-farm channels; water courses and drainage systems; (ii) lack of access and control over canal water flows to assure timely irriga- tion; (iii) lack of access to credit to finance irrigation works,
 -vi - and, among tenants, lack of secure and clear titles to land, which provides the main collateral for medium-term loans;and (iv) ineffi- cient and at times even excessive use of surface irrigation in the fields. For qroundwater irriqation (wells and tubewells) these problems include (i) the lack of investable funds and medium-term credits; (ii) economies of scale in tubewell irrigation that miLli- tate against private ownership on small holdings; (iii) lack of control over public wells and tubewells;and (iv) most criticalLy, the fragmentation of holdings which prevents any rational or effi- cient use of groundwater irrigation systems. At best one :an hope that small farmers, who irrigate a larger proportion of their cultivated area, wi.ll get their proportional share--that is the share of irrigated area that they now command--of the additional irrigation potential currently being exploited in South Asia. Without irrigation they will be permanently cut off from the benefits of new technologies. 21. The potential for additional irriqation is very large, at least in Bangladesh and India. (In Pakistan nearly 3/4 of the area is already irrigated and the potential here is not at the extensive margin but rather at the intensive margin--that is in using water and conveying it effectively through canals to the farmers' fields). But irrigation is plagued in all three coun- tries by the severe fraqmentation of holdinqs and the associated problems of riparian rights tnat have led to an under-exploittation of their enormous irrigation potentials. Little progress has been made in solving these critical problems that affect all farmers. 22. In addition, building up the necessary institutional framework, economic viability and administrative capacity to install and exploit complex surface command area and groundwater irrigation systems and then assure small farmers' access to them poses the main challenge in South Asian agriculture. 23. The scope for increasing productivity differs little bet.wo' small farms and other farms, except pernaps in Paxistan where the former account for only 5 percent of the cultivated area, An aqqre- gate 3.5 - 4% per annum qrowth in agricultural production for Bang- ladesh and India seems quite feasible. Pakistan has achieved rates of growth in agricultural production in excess of 4.0% during the past decade and a half, but with some signs of decelerationa in recent years.
 -vii - V. Inst:Ltutional Constraints: Problems of Access to Factor and Product Markets Credit 24. Although lack of credit is often cited as a major constraint, it is ne:ither necessary nor sufficient for increased productivity on small farms. The central need is for technologies that offer reliable and well proven yield increases to persuade risk-averse small farmers to depart from traditional practices. Where these are unavailable credit will not suffice; where they are, credit remains at best an enabling condition, and becomes more readily available. 25. Small farmers pay more for the credit they get because they rely more heavily on non-institutional sources,which charge higher interest rates but also offer more flexibility and bear higher associated risks. Attempts to replace these sources with institu- tional credits without offering equivalent flexibility, terms and risk acceptability are unlikely to succeed. 26. Subsidized interest rates for small farmers, apart from being administratively infeasible, create problems of inefficient use of capital and artificial credit scarcity from which small farmers seldom benefit. Subsidies for small farmers can be justified on several crounds but it is a mistake to use the credit mechanism as a vehicle for such subsidies. 27. Small farmer credit problems are probably more severe in Pakistan than in Bangladesh and India. This is partly due to the neglect of credit. institutions generally and partly due to the slower growth of credit cooperatives, especially those geared to small farmer needs. The more rapid adoption of new technologies by small farmers in recent years will tend to make credit institu- tions more able and willing to serve small farmer needs, as they have in India and Bangladesh. 28. The greatest need small farmers have is not for short-term production credits, which non-institutional sources readily provide, but for medium-term credits to finance equipment (tubewells) and farm improvements.. Both the size and terms of such loans preclude the traditional sources from providing these credits. This is an area where new credit institutions can play a positive role by increasing the volume of medium-term credits (without necessarily subsidizing interest rates) to small farmers. The problem will be one of Droper collateral. As land is the most common form of colla- teral, srnall farmers--and especially tenants, whose rights are neither acknowledged nor secure--have systematically been denied access to medium- and long-term credits. The alternative is to use crop outputs as collateral and provide crop loans, but these
 - viii - require the proper recordina of crop and input-cost shares and present problems of a different nature. Nonetheless innovative methods and new institutions are needed to attack these medium- and long-term credit problems if small and tenant farmers are to benefit increasingly from technological innovations. 29. Although credit cooperatives have been more receptive to small farmers' needs, and offer one alternative, their impact has been limited because small farmers have been unable to control them through participation at the decision-making level. They also suffer from poor management and financi,al instability, and have not been able to keep up with the rapid increase in the demand for credit in the wake of the cash-intensive "green-revolution" technologies. Markets 30. Small farmers are not isolated but well inteqrated into local markets In South Asia. Although several marketing problems exist-- inadequate trans2ort, storage facilities, poor dissemination of information, lack of standards, large numbers of intermediaries, inadequate finance for trading--these problems are not peculiar to small farmers. Nor are traditional and local markets in which small farmers participate necessarily inefficient or exploitative, as is often maintained. 31. Government regulation of markets has invariably led to illicit trade, increased intermediation and marketing costs that have not been beneficial to small farmers, 32. Special c9nditions that aggravate marketing problems for small farmers include (i) the necessity--imposed by the need to meet cash and debt obligations--to sell cheap at post-harvest prices and buy back dear at pre-harvest prices; (ii) small farmers' smaller leverage in negotiating favorable terms because of the small volume of their output marketed;and (iii) the higher cost credit they obtain to tide them from pre- to post-harvest periods. 330 These-problems can only partly be resolved through marketing cooperatives which suffer from problems similar to credit cooperatives=' poor management, financial instability and subversion by powerful (usually large farmer) interests.
 - ix - Extension, Research and Education 34. Public institutions set up to provide these services have denied small farmers access and have failed to deliver knowledge that is appropriate to small farmer needs. They need to be tho- roughly reorganized and experiments with new organizational forms are needed to assure that the services these institutions provide become more available and relevant to small farmers. 35. Educated small farmers are the key element. A failure to achieve near universal rates of rural literacy will continue to be an important hindrance to the ability of rural people, especially small farmers, to adopt and manage new technologies effectively and to control rural institutions, supposedly designed for their benefit but subverted by the more literate rural elites. 36. Agricultural research needs to focus on: (i) new high yielding varieties for arid crops and arid agricultural systems; (ii) the development and breeding of livestock; (iii) nutrient and water use efficiency in multiple cropping systems;and (iv) cropping systems and practices suitable for the cash-scarce and labor-abundant con- ditions of the small farmer. 37. In India agricultural research and extension are well developed and can be rapidly adapted to focus on these problems. In Bangladesh, although the extension systems are well developed and could be quickly reorganized, the basic research institutions are not sufficiently developed to devise the complex multiple cropping systems needed by most farmers. Developing these research institutions is crucial. In Pakistan both the research and extension systems are relatively under-developed and will need considerable investment to bring them to a level consistent with Pakistan's future needs. A different focus of research in Pakistan will have to be on the efficiency of water use in a complex multi-crop environment and the efficiency of water conveyance to farmers' fields.
 VI. Non-Farm Employment and the Landless 38. Non-farm and non-crop activities will continue to be a primary source of employment and earnings for the landless, near-lanaiess and marginal farmers. Activities such as raising poultry and live- stock, especially small stock and dairying, are important sources of income. Irn particular, dairy projects under a variety of coope- rative ventures hlave been highly successful and have provided sub- stantial income gains to large numbers of landless, marginals and small farmers. These ventures are now being tried in ne.zly 10 of the 14 Indian states and in Pakistan. 39. The number of landless families in South Asia is not known with any certainty. Our best estimates suggest that there may be more than 30 million landless households in South Asia. These households nave to rely primarily on the growth of wage employment in the rural sector. 40. There are two sources for such employment growth: on-farm demand for wage labor, and non-farm employment in processing, fisheries, forestry, marketing, transportation, distribution and services in rural areas. The growth of both these sources of employment depends upon and is highly correlated with the rate of growth of agricultural output. 41. The available evidence suggests that unless agricultural growth exceeds 3 - 4% per annum and that unless this rate is sustained for at least a decade, the additional wage employment generated will remain small and is not likely to contribute much to the solution of rural unemployment. The percentages of the rural population unemployed or underemployed are already very large and the rural labor force is growing at rates in excess of 2% per annum. So a hiqh and sustained rate of agricultural qrowth is both a necessary and a sufficient condition for high rates of qrowth of non-farm employment opportunities. Rural unemployment in South Asia will never be solved if agriculture is stagnant. 42. Although rural work proqrams serve a useful purpose in relieving disasters, they have generally had no significant impact on rural employment. In South Asia the sheer maqnitude of the task will continue to defeat their purpose, if this purpose is to mate subs- tantial inroads into rural unemployment. For this we will have to look to vigorous agricultural growth.
 xi - 43. Finally there are the questions of land reform and tenancY reform. Regarding land reforms the considered opinion is that the opportunity for radical reformist action has already past in South Asia. 44. Small tenant holdings (holdings of less than five acres that are wholly or partly rented) account for a large share of all holdings and total cultivated area especially in India and Bangladesh. Smail Tenants as a percentage of Total: Holdings Cultivated Area Bangladesh 25 20 India. 22 8 Pakistan 11 2 45. Regarding tenancy there are two issues: (i) to what extent will productivity increases on tenant farms accrue as incomes to small tenants; and (ii) what tenancy reforms would improve their lot? As to the first question, at present we do not know how much of the potential productivity increases, if realized, will accrue to tenants. In any given case this will depend on such factors as the length of tenure, the landlards' and tenants' rental shares of output, the amount of land rented, the arrangements regarding the sharing of input costs, the cropping pattern and the technologies used--factors that cannot be easily generalized. Further, tenancy contracts have been changing in recent years as technological innovations have spread, making assumptions about rental shares more difficult. Rental shares are about 50 percent at present so that as a rough estimate at least half the productivity increases would accrue to small tenants. But this is only a guess and additional work is needed before we can resolve this issue. 46. Regarding tenancy refoim the best suggestions are to (i' reduce the rental shares tenants have to pay, (ii) encourage input-cost sharing, and (iii) confer security of tenure. A rough estimate is that a reduction of the rental share to a maximum of 25 percent could raise tenant incomes by more than half. This would require the recording of all leases and the enforcement -f the maximum rental shares. Both present serious administrative and poli- tical problems as does the conferring of security. Input-cos: sharing may be the only alternative remaining, and th,ere is evidence that this is already being undertakern. Finally, whatet\wer tenancy reforms are enacted are unlikely to solve the problems of the Landless, wL- will have to continue to rely on wage emplo7ment.
 - xii - 47. The experience with rural work programs as a means for providing employment in South Asia has been mixed. although they serve a very useful purpose in the relief of r-udden disasters, the salient fact is that they have had only an insignificant impact on the magnitude of the rural unemployment problem, except in very few cases and in a limited regional context. In South Asia, whatever the organizational, productivity, implementation and fiscal problems associated with the development of rural work programs, the sheer maqniti'de of the task will continue to defeat their purpose, if this purpose is to make substantial inroads into rural unemployment. For this we will have to look to vigorous agrl- cultural growth. A stagnant agriculture will continue to assure an increasing and insurmountable rural unemployment problem for decades to come in South Asia.
 Chapter I: INTRODUCTION: THE SCOPE OF THE PROBLEM The majority of the world's poor reside in rural South Asia. 1/ The rural poor are predominantly small farmers-- some of whom own land, but most of whom are tenants--with cultivated holdings of less than 5 acres (2 hectares), and the landless. Any programs aimed at either the eradication of rural poverty or the acceleration of growth in the agricultural sector have to increase the productivity of the former an.l the employment opportunities for the latter. The purpose of this paper is to examine the extent to which (i) small farmer productivity increases are possible, (ii) institu- tional and other constraints prevent such increases and (iii) employ- ment and income opportunities can be found for the landless in South Asia. In particular we want to find out whether significant increases in small farmer productivity are feasible and what separate or inte- grated measures have been tried, where and with what success. Further, we want to assess in general terms what, if any, have been the insti- tutional constraints that have prevented small farmers from realizing their productive potential. Finally we want to assess what, if any- thing, can be done to relieve the conditions of poverty in which many small tenants and the landless survive in the sub-continent. The subject matter is vast and the conditions bearing on these problems are complex and diverse. A treatment of these issues in- evitably involves not only a detailed examination of the microeconomic evidence at the farm level--in conditions of enormous agronomic, cli- matic, institutional and economic diversity--but also an understanding of the aggregate structure of the rural economies and the social, cultural and political relationships in which individual decisions to obtain a better standard of living are embedded. Obviously, not all these issues can be dealt with in a single paper; the main focus of the present study is on the potential for increases in the pro- ductivity of small farms, and on the income gains that would result. The problems of massive rural unemployment in South Asia and the conditions of the landless are treated less fully, not because they are unimportant but because to a large extent any lasting solution would inevitably e-tail either massive institutional changes (land reform) of a type unlikely to take place given present political realities, or in their absence, vigorous and sustained growth in agricultural productivity and output in which small farmers would participate fully. 1/ South Asia throughout the paper is used to denote the three largest countries of the sub-continent - Bangladesh, India and Pakistan.
 The paper is organized as follows: the remainder of this Chapter describes the broad magnitudes of the problem in terms of numbers of small farm, tenant and landless households in South Asia; Chapter 2 characterizes the "small farm" in terms of the size of the family holding and other economic characteristics; Chapter 3 examines the extent to which small farmer productivity can be increased by changes in simple cropping practices, and the adoption of scientific multiple cropping systems without an increase in any inputs otler than the amount of family labor and the quality of farm management. Chapter 4 then examines what additional productivity incrc -es can be obtained through increased nutrient use and the adoption of new HYVs on small farms under unirrigated and irrigated conditions for the main foodgrain crops, which account for between 85 - 90% o:E small farm cropped areas. It also reviews briefly the large irrigation potential in South Asia and the problems small farmers may encounter in obtaining their fair share from its anticipated exploitation. Chapter 5 examines the institutional problems associated witti small farmers' access to credit, markets, extension, research and education-- all seen as essential to increasing their productivity; finally Chapter 6 examines the magnitude of non-farm employment in rural areas and the potentials for increasing the incomes of small farmers and the landless through these activities. Using these figures we calculate that with rural populations of nearly 625 million, there are an estimated 110.8 million rural house- holds (average household size in 5.6) in South Asia. Of these, nearly 75.1 million are cultivating households. Of the cultivating house- holds some 51.5 million operate less than five acres, and probably support a total population of some 253 million. Nearly 15.5 million of all cultivating households operate either wholly or partly under some form of tenant-landlord relationship and support some 80 million people,but have to share the fruits of their labors with landlords. Finally, an estimated 30.9 million households may be totally land- less and support a population of some 157 million people by their wage labor alone in environments where unemployment and underemployment are widespread. 1/ The estimates of landlessness in Pakistan are probably the most unreliable of these estimates. Further,what can one make of only 45% of its rural households in cultivation? What are the other 55% doing and how do we reconcile this with the low percentage of landless population? The questions can be asked but not easily answered.
 Chapter II: SMALL FARMERS AND SMALL FARM CHARACTERISTICS While the major emphasis of agricultural strategies in the sub- continent must be on increasing food production, it should be explicitly recognized that small farmers have an important role in expanding production, and that increased production by these farmers=- a larqe segment of the rural poor--can assist significantly in an attack on poverty. A strategy to reduce poverty aimed specifically at small farmers is especially important because: - the majority of the small farmers are among the abject poor in rural areas; - individuals in this group have access to land (although their farms are small) and they are engaged in production activities that provide gainful employment at least most of the year; - among all small producers a high percentage of the land is often used for food crops. As one of the most direct and visible consequences of poverty is malnutrition, any measures designed to increase productivity, especially of food crop cultivation on small farms, are likely to have a major and direct impact on nutrition. (The marginal propensity to con- sume food out of production is in the range of .75 to 09 in most cases.) But what is a small farmer, how can he be identified and how many small farmers are there in South Asia? A0 Concept of the Small Farmer Usually a small farmer is taken to be synonymous with a poor farmer, 1/ but farm size alone is an inadequate criterion for dis- tinguishing poor farmers from those better off. Net per capita income is the only true measure for this. However, to estimate it requires very detailed and frequently unobtainable data on the types of crops grown, the types of inputs used, the crop yields, the costs of cultivation, the money value of gross output and, of course, off-farm incomes earned and the size of the household. Alternative 1/ While a relatively high proportion of small landholding households are poor, not all "poor" households are drawn from this category, nor are all small holders poor0 Thus, Vaidyanathan (1974) shows in India households with less than one acre accounted for no more than 20% of all households with per capita consumption of less than Rs. 10 per month in 1951-57. Roughly a fifth of all households with less than an acre had per capita monthly consumption exceeding Rs. 1l at 1960-61 prices,which was defined as the "poverty line" in his study.
 -9- measures, such as gross farm income or the proportion of off-farm to total incomie earned, present similar problems. Even if such measures of income were available, where the cut-off line should be drawn to identify small farmers is always an arbitrary decision. At any rate, no adequate data exist to allow us to map farm incomes of any type into numbers of small farm holdings in South Asia at an aggregate level. 1/ Data limitations make a definition based on area operated diffi- cult to avoid, despite the extreme regional diversity of production systems in South Asia, with respect to rainfall, soil fertility, irrigation and other factors affecting land quality and intensity of input use. Even these statistics are not always reliable and data from different sources are sometimes inconsistent. However, the size of operated holding provides a first and only available cut at the problem, at an aggregate level. 1/ The Indian Agricultural Refinance and Development Corporation (ARDC), one of the main recipients of IDA funds for agricultural development, classifies small farmers as those with pre-project family income in 1972 prices of less than Rs 2,000 (US$235) per annum. This is equivalent to a per capita income of about US$70 per annum at today's prices. ARDC has translated this "pre-project income" into an area equivalent for every district in India. Where ecological variations are significant within a district, ARDC has broken the district into smaller units. Applying their definition, a small farmer may be one with a farm of 3.5 ac. in better rainfall areas, or over 40 ac. in the more arid parts of India. This range of farms with the same pre- project income illsutrates the dangers of using a single area-based figure as the criterion to define a small farmer. However, using "pre-project income" to define a small farmer is not without its drawbacks. For example, applying the ARDC definition, a farmer with 4 ac. unirrigated land but with reliable rainfall (say, in Kerala) may fall outside the small farmer definition, while a farmer with 10 ac. on the Deccan Plateau, where raInfall is unreliable, may classify as a small farmer. It may well be true that the 10 ac. farmer is worse off than his 4 ac. counterpart, but this says nothing about potential. It is likely that the potential of the farmer on the Deccan Plateau with irrigation exceeds that of the Kerala farmer on a per ha basis. Thus, by directing resources, say irrigation, at the "smaller farmer" as defined by pre-project income (the 10 ac. farmer on the Deccan Plateau) one creates a very large and profitable farmer, worsening income distribution.
 - 10 - In order not to be totally arbitrary, we use the concept of a family ho1ding, defined as "a holding that would yield adequate income to maintain average farm family at a nutritionally desirable level of living." U We have calculated this in terms of the land needed for family subsistence by computing the calories requ:ired by an average family per year and dividing that by the average rice or wheat yields over the past five and ten years for Pakistan, 13angla- desh and the different states in India. The results are shown in Table 2.1. They indicate quite clearly that in India, whether in the rice or the wheat zone, about 2 to 2.5 acres of land a required to maintain an average family in subsistence. 2/ These requirements of course vary from one state to another, from a low of 1.2 to 1.3 acres in Punjab and Tamil Nadu, to nearly 3.5-4 acres in a4adhya Pradesh and Nagaland depending upon the average yields in these states. A similar exercise for Pakistan and Bangladesh yields land requirements of approximately 2.5 - 3 acres per family.. These estimates define absolute minimum subsistence requirements, and since they are based on average yields, they do not account for yield variations, which can be substantial from year to year in the sub-continent. To assure the family of survival, say at least 9 out of every 10 years, would require at least twice as much land as de- fined by this absolute minimum. 3/ Of course, there are offsetting factors: intensity of cultivation, off-farm incomes, better manage- ment, higher input use, make it possible to meet this minimum from much smaller holdings. On the other hand, the existence of tenure and share holding arrangements and low productive semi-arid and rainfed areas make it necessary to have much larger holdings on the average. For the purpose of this paper we define three broad size categories. First, what one might readily call marginal farmers, with less than 2.5 acres, who live very close to the margin of subsistence, especially if they rely only on farm incomes. Second, small farmers, wi-th 2.5 - 5 acres per family. 4/ Third, families with less than I acre of operated holding. These might be called the near-landless, since their pro- ductive potential is too small to meet even their subsistence needs.  - 13 - We have so far considered some of the problems of using a single absolute definition of small farmers. The term "small" farmer has a relative as well as an absolute connotation. For example, as Table 2.3 shows, if 2.5 acres were the cut-off point, then only 14% of farms in Pakistan would be classified as "small", against over 50% of the Indian and Bangladesh farms. But in Pakistan, where the average farm sizes about 11 acres, it possibly makes sense to talk about an 8 acre farmer as a small farmer, while his counterpart in India would be a larger farmer. Because of the difficulties of reach- ing a satisfactory definition of a small farmer that allows for easy aggregation of numbers of small farmers, either within a country or between countries, we have used the term loosely throughout this paper. According to these definitions then, nearly 70% of the holdings in India can be classified as small, marginal or near-landless. These account for nearly 21% of the area. In Pakistan, only 28% can be classified in these categories and they account for only 5% of the cultivated area. In Bangladesh, finally some 83% of the holdings must be classified as small, marginal or near-landless, and these account for nearly 51% of the total area cultivated. The near- landless are an especially large category accounting for 33% of the holdings in India and 25% in Bangladesh. (See Table 2.3). Over the decade 1960-70 in India and Bangladesh there was a drastic downwqard shift in the size distribution of holdings (Tables 2.4 - 2.7). As population pressure has increased, the number of small holdings has increased, although their average size has not changed much. Whereas in 1960-61 holdings of less than 5 acres accounted for 62% of the holdings and 18 1/2% of the total cultivated area in India, by 1970-71 they accounted for 70% of the holdings and 21% of the cultivated area. The most dramatic changes took place for holdings of less than one acre: whereas in 1960-61 they accounted for only 18% of the holdings, by 1970-71 they accounted for 33%. The data for Bangladesh reveal a similar dismal trend. Households with less than 5 acres accounted for 77% of the holdings and 42% of the area in 1960*-61; by 1967-68 they accounted for 83% of the holdings and 51% of thle area. The data for Pakistan reveal an opposite trend. Holdings of less than 5 acres in 1960-61 accounted for 49% of the holdings and 10% of the cultivated area; by 1972 they accounted for only 28% of the holdings and only 5% of the area. The changes in Pakistan have come mainly through an increase in the medium (7.5 - 25 acres) and large farm sizes (50 to 150 acres) while in Bangladesh and India the shift has been from holdings of between 5 and 12 acr(es to holdings of less than 2.5 acres.

 - I s- B. Small Farm Characteristics Most small farmers share a set of common characteristics. These characteristics define the economic parameters for policy actions, and a proper understanding of them is a first necessary step toward increasing small farmer productivity. They include: - A high proportion of land devoted to food crops in orde:r to meet family subsistence needs. - A high proportion of output that is retained for home consumption or, inversely, a lower ratio of marketed surplus to output. 1/ - A diverse mixture of crops that allows them to hedge rationally against both agro-climatic (weather, yields) and market (output prices) risks. Crops are often interplanted. - A higher degree of risk aversion when faced with either new or rapidly changing market, technology or policy conditions. Given the small margins that separate their output expectations from disaster (starvation) such 'safety first' risk-averse behaviour is highly rational and attests to their good economic sense. - Very low operating capital turnover in production coupled often with a higher debt burden in relation to their resources. This contradiction is due to their need to borrow heavily for consump- tion purposes in order to sustain the family from one production cycle to another. Thus, paradoxically, they rely heavily upon creditors but use little of their borrowed capital directly for production. 2/ - Labor, not surprisingly, is the most important input into pro- duction as it is relatively abundant. Most of it is supplied by the family. Scarce factors like land and capital are econo- mized, and factor proportions reflect higher labor intensities in production. l/ This is on an annual basis.  - 21 - Chapter III: INCREASING SMALL FARMER PRODUCTIVITY The main constraints on increasing productivity on small farms are of various types. They include: the acrronomic and technological constraints such as the quality of land, the amount of water available, the climate, soils, their fertility, the type of seeds and nutrients used, the cropping practices followed, the type of pest infestations and disease, and finally the yield responses to the use of various inputs. The major problem in this area is the limited availability of agricultural technologies specially adapted to small farm con- ditions. The remedy is to emphasize labor-intensive, cash- saving, skill-and management-saving technologies that are suited to small farm systems. This point is discussed in some detail below. econornic constraints that have to do with how farmers respond to market and other incentives. These constraints ultimately stem from the low productivity and incomes that result from poor output prices and limited incentives for marketing, and the effects of these limited incentives on the crops grown and the technologies used. They also include such problems as the limited amount of off-farm employment (due to slow overall growth in other sectors) available to those who cannot increase their income sufficiently through technological change. The remedies are to change policies so as to make it easier and more profitable for small farmers to adopt technologies that would increase their incomes, and to increase employment oppor- tunities in the non-farm sector so as to provide employment opportunities in rural areas; - institutional constraints that limit farmers' access to research, extension, credit, marketing, and power and transportation infra- structure. The solution lies in the reorientation and redesign of institutions (for credit, for marketing, for extension) so that they can serve the needs of small farmers; - structural constraint, that center around the problems of small uneconomic holdings, extent and security of tenure, the rate of rent charged to tenant holders. The solution to this fourth set of problems, of course, lies in the areas of tenancy and land reform, land consolidation and the redistribution of land-- the most critical asset in rural areas;
 - 22 - socio-cultural constraints that have to do with the social and cultural development of rural people, and the limited understanding among economists of the traditional SystE>ms of which the small farmer is a part. The solution lies in providing rural education, increased rural literacy, and training for farmers, so as to give them greater exposure to science and technology, and paying more attention to adaptive research so that technologies are suited to their needs; - finally, there are political constraints which center earound the lack of political commitment to agriculture and particularly to small farm agriculture. The remedy for this, of course, lies with governments themselves. Such a commitment is unlikely to be made unless governments are aware of both the severity of the problems and the states involved and, in part, of the types of solutions that are available to solve them. Leaving aside the socio-cultural and political constraints, the limitations on small farmers' ability to raise their productivity operate through four distinct but connected sets of relationships: - Agronomic-technological relationshi s. How far output can be increased by changes in the application of inputs, using a given technology, depends partly upon the level at which inputs are presently being used by small farmers and pairtly upon the marginal response of outputs to the inputs being used. - Economic relationships between input and output prices (hence pricing policies) determine whether it is economically profitable for small farmers to use given inputs more inten- sively at any given margin. Price relationships also dleter- mine the share of the input costsor the output benefits that accrues to small farmers. For tenants, the terms of tenancy are a critical factor in decisions about whether to rai.se output. Tax and subsidy policies, and the efficiencies with which resources are used, also affect the profitability to farmers of raising production. - Institutional relationships pertain to the way in which markets as well as non-market (public-private) institutions function or fail to function for small farmers, thus deter- mining their conditions of access to knowledge of new inputs or to the inputs themselves. Monopoly and monopsony condi- tions in commodity and factor markets in rural areas tend to bias these markets against the economically weak.
 - 23 - - Structural Relationships pertain to the conditions of tenancy (both economic and non-economic-feudal relationships) and the distribution of land and other productive assets in rural areas. These initial conditions cannot be changed withouit a major overhaul of the entire economic, social and political relationships in an economy. 1/ Thus, in determining what factors (inputs and institutional changes) are likely to increase small farmer productivity, we need to ask (i) whlat inputs are likely to increase the output (yield per hectare) of small farmers, and by how much? (ii) are these yield increases likely to accrue as increased incomes to small farmers, and if so by how much? (iii) do small farmers have knowledge of as well as access to new inputs and to institutions that serve them, and if not, how can their access be increased? and (iv) are changes in structural relationships (tenure conditions and the pize distribution of holdings) a precondition for increases in small farmer productivity? A. Cropping Practices Perhaps the most important small farmer characteristic is the availability of labor and the scarcity of cash, knowledge, management and organizational skills. An approach to raising productivity that uses labor but saves on cash and management skills has been recommended by Benor and Harrison (1977). The fundamental concept underlying their extension message is to get farmers to do simple things that could increase output immediately, and which extension workers could be easily taught to carry to farmers. Nothing is recommended that does not increase farmers' income and, most importantly, the initial concentration is on improving agricultural management practices. These practices include better land preparation, improved seed bed and nursery maintenance, increased plant populations, use of good seed (including appropriate improved varieties), seed treatment, tilling operations, weeding, the proper spacing of plants and so on. It should be emphasized that the initial stress is on improving management practices for several reasons. First, these improved cultural practices are said to produce sure results: in adopting them the farmers face little risk. Second, while these improved practices need more work they require little or no cash outlay. Third, the ability to derive the full benefit from new production technologies depends on having first learnt good crop management. For example, if farmers apply fertilizers to a field that is not properly weeded or the stands of 1/ This paper cannot possibly cover all the issues related to these distinct aspects of the Problem. The result can be a lower crop yield rather than higher one. Under the Benor-Harrison approach, these practices are at first recommended only for a small part of farmers' land, so that they do not appear unduly risky, and so that their results can be compared with those of traditional practices in farmers own fields. Since these practices are normally quite "well known and tested' (so Benor and Harrison maintain), 1/ they can be fed into an extension service readily without requiring an elaborate, time-consuming screening and trial process. Benor and Harrison's method has been found readily assimilable in a wide variety of rain-fed and irrigated conditions in a number of developing countries. In Turkey, farmers are supposed to have increased their cotton yields from 1.7 to 3 tons per hectare in three years. In Madhya Pradesh unirrigated and irrigated wheat yields rose from 1.3 tons to nearly 2 tons per hectare after one season, a nearly 54% increase. The area under high yielding paddy and wheat varieties in the entire state of West Bengal is reported to have increasedc sub- stantially in a single year. As far as can be determined, these rapid increases in farm output were not primarily due to an increase in irrigation, better weather, discovery of a new variety or more fertilizer. In Rajasthan, for example, it was reported that yields increased while the use of purchased inputs declined. Although the aggregate data for South Asia suggest that multiple cropping could be increased substantially, they do not reflect the true potential on small farms. The data in Table 3.10 show that although only 9% of the cultivated area is multiple-cropped in India and 10% in Pakistan, the area multiple-cropped on farms smaller than 5 acres ranges from 16% - 27% for India and from 30% - 52% for Pakistan. Further, multiple cropping is inversely related to farm size, as one would expect. (Small farmers farm their land more intensively, having the available family labor to do it; hence their yield per unit area per unit of time is much higher than on large farms.) In Bangladesh the figures are even more dramatic. Whereas 53% of the cultivated area in Bangladesh is multiple cropped, the figures for farms less than 5 acres show a multiple-cropped area of 58% - 82%. Indeed, for farms under 1 acre the cropping intensity is almost as high as that in the Republic of China, often cited as the prime exponent of effective multiple cropping systems. For more small farms in India and Pakis-0 tan to produce two crops per year will eventually depend upon the availability of irrigation and other inputs. In Bangladesh, on the other hand, farmers on the average are already getting nearly two crops a year, so we are really talking about trying to get three crops a year. The management demands of multiple cropping can be substantial. Necessary (but not sufficient) conditions for the wider adopticn of multiple cropping include (i) the use of imrproved varieties; (ii) better water control; (iii) further inputs of fertilizer; (iv) better insect and disease controls; and (v) more efficient post- harvest technologies. l/ See Table 3. for definition of the multiple cropping index. Thus, the substantial potential for multiple cropping in South Asia cannot be realized without increased water control, without the development of new varieties, without increased fertilizer use, without the proper control of insects, disease and weeds, or, finally, the development of appropriate rotational systems. The poten- tial is considerably less for small than for larger farmers, first because they are already cropping their land more intensively, second, because their access to these necessary new inputs may be limited, and finally because to increase the area under multiple cropping, especiall with cropping intensity over 150% - 160%, requires a huge advance in farmers' management capability. Small farmers are shrewd decision makers, but they generally lack the literacy and knowledge to handle complex crop systems scientifically. The most critical management problem is of course timing. In South Asia, with its year-round sunshine and no climatic barriers to three or even four crops a year, the key obstacle is the length or timing of the traditional growing season. 1/ As more crops are planted within a given season and the growing period between them is shortened, it is clear that less time is left between the harvest of one crop and the planting of the next. Minimizing the number of days the land is left idle is a very heavy burden on the farm manager. A large number of operations need to be carried out in a relatively short period. The relatively abundant supply of labor on small farms may work to their advantage here. But as regards other inputs, small farmers may be at a disadvantage. If seeds, nutrients and irrigation water are not available on time, they might as well not be available, and if the small farmers have to stand in line to get these inputs, then their timing is upset and the probability of succeeding with multiple cropping practices is reduced. It is noteworthy that even where adaptive research has provided appropriate cropping rotations which could be used in parts of India and Bangladesh, the problem of timing has prevented their wider adoptic I/ Thus, for example, in Northeast India where there is plentiful rain it has not been possible to sow a wheat crop on the land in addition to rice because the paddy takes at least 5 1/2 months to matuire and harvesting is seldom completed before the middle of December. Similarly, in Bihar and Eastern U.P. the nursery beds are planted in June and the seedlings are not ready to be trans- planted until late July or early August. As a result, the crop does not ripen until late autumn when days are relatively short and nights are cold, so that a second crop is not possible.

High Yielding Varieties and Nutrient Use Although the "green revolution" technologies are supposed to be technically scale-neutral, it has been argued that small farmers have adopted them to a far smaller degree because they have not had adequate access to the necessary inputs, and hence that the grins have gone disproportionately or even solely to large farmers. 1/ The evidence from research is not conclusiveo _ The fairly extensive evidence from India is mixed. He noted rapid rates of adoption of HYV wheat, but that the majority of rice growers had preferred to retain traditional strains because of their certain, althouch lower, yields. Especially in the eastern belt of India, which lay outside the purview of the new technology, a large proportion of the culti- vated rice area was in small holdings. He noted the deterioration of tenurinl conditions as a direct consequence of the green revo- lution and warned against what he termed "the old squeeze whereby tenants are reduced to sharecroppers, eventually to landless workers, as more of the bigger owners become involved with the new tech- nologies.' He agreed that the green revolution was neutral to scale, because its inputs were divisible, but that this neutrality broke down when it came to securing credit.  - 5 3 - In a detailed study on the use of nutrients for the maize crop in Bihar, Ojha (1970) noted that the per acre application of various fertilizer nutrients was much lower on small farms. The percentage of farmers using recommended dosages was much lower among small farmers, as were the average expenditures per acre on chemical fertilizer for both hybrid as well as local varieties. As a consequence, as all small farmers planted larger proportions of their area under hybrid maize than did larger farmers, they tended to spread the fertilizer more thinly. As a result , yields were much lower on small farms. Credit was a critical constraint. Schluter and Mellor (1972) noted that small farmers were particularly willing to innovate where this was profitable and not unduly risky. Thus, over time, small farmers increased the acreage under new varieties, but this increase was consistent with credit being a constraint on their adoption of new varieties. Through 1967-69, small farmers were lagging in adoption, having to rely heavily on credit. The joint problem of credit and uncertainty also affected the choice of cropping pattern. Further, Schluter and Mellor found that to the extent that small farmers used coop- erative credit and large farmers used their own funds, the former may have had to pay more for credit than large farms. Michie (1973) found that although there was evidence of higher yields per a,cre on small farms, lack of access to critical inputs prevented small farmers from taking full advantage of the new technologies. Similarly, Dasgupta's (1977) study showed no evidence that the new technology was "percolating" from large to smaller farms, while there was a growing inequality in land distribution and the new technology had no discernible positive impact on income distribution. Frankel (1971) found that in rice growing regions,where the majority of farmers have uneconomic holdings of 2-3 acres, the increased yields have been too low to create adequate capital either to develop land or to increase yields further. The few yield increases that have occurred have been offset by the rising cost of living for the small farmer, where land has to be leased. Thus she argues that the economic conditions of the small farmer deteriorated absolutely. Most income from increased yields due to high application of ferti- lizers is spent on consumption; in a few instances in West Bengal it has been used to purchase modern inputs. Lipton (1977) argues that the price incentives affecting the adoption of high-yielding varieties appeared to have favored larger farmers. He cites evidence from Rao (1972), Bari (1975) and Swenson (1973) to argue that large farmers in South India made substantial
 - 34 - gains from increased production and privileged market access in the wake of the high-yielding varieties. The smaller farmers who were latecomers invariably benefited less because the output growth achieved in the earlier stages brought down the relative prices of crops concerned. This price structure therefore (i) reduced small farmers' capacity,relative to that of large farmers, to repay and obtain loans, (ii) cumulatively increased the bigger farmers. capacity to finance further innovations, and (iii) forced smell farmers to pay high input prices, while decreasing their cash return on high-yielding varieties. Lipton also cites small farmers" limited access to credit as limiting their output. Evidence from studies by Wills (1972) of Uttar Pradesh, and by Raj Purohit (1972) of Mysore, also suggests that lack of credit is a major barrier to access to new technologies. Traditional credit, Lipton argues, at times requires a lien, sometimes a hereditary lien, on some of the borrower's labor, especially if he happens to rent part of his land. If the loan cannot be repaid, his labor may be called upon at times when it is needed by the small producer himself. This may not only discourage but prevent the small farmer from buying modern inputs. All these studies contend that either small farmers have not taken up new technologies or that their adoption has been limited by access to inputs: water, fertilizers and most critically credit. Similarly, a study by Faidley and Esmay (1976) showed that small and large farmers appeared to have adopted improved rice varieties at about the same rate, and to be cultivating with equal success.  - 57 - In a study of the cooperative system in the Comilla scheme, Bose (1974) has shown the successful adoption of new technology on small farms and a fair distribution of the benefits to farmers irrespective of their size of holdings. Bose also contends that these new technologies have done nothing directly for the landless and the very small farmers -- those with less than one hectare. Most of the farmers in Bangladesh are small farmers, and, on an overall basis, the uptake of new technologies has been slower in Bangladesh than in other parts of the sub-continent. The evidence from Pakistan shows much more clearly that the gains from new technologies and nutrients have gone disproportionately to larger farmers. Only a smattering of evidence exists to show that small farms have adopted the new technologies. Salam (1973) from a sample of 19 districts in the Punjab (where 90% of his sample farms had applied chemical fertilizers) found that the use of nutrients was-significantly higher on small farms, and that they were using higher amounts of land-saving factor inputs, such as fertilizer. The sourcs of financing for these inputs werepersonal savings and non-institutional credit sources,which were the most important source, especially for small farms. Similarly,;Kaneda and Naseem (1972) also observed the ease with which divisible inputs were adopted by small farmers in the Punjab. Even though tubewells are lumpy inputs, small farmers in the Punjab were taking advantage of these too. The Pakistan evidence on the opposite side is much more extensive. For example, Amjad (1972) argued that though since the late 1960s the application of fertilizers on high yielding varieties had become a very important source for productive increases in Pakistan, most of the area not covered by high yielding varieties was on small farms. Amjad gave four reasons for this: (i) it was not profitable at government-support prices; (ii) they were unable to undertake the necessary financial investments; and (iii) the important inputs were monopolized by large farmers. He argued that in 1972 nearly 80% of the farms less than 5 acres used no fertilizers, apparently due to lack of funds and irrigation. These reasons also restricted the application of nutrients on 7 to 12 acre farms to half the average per acre used on larger farms, whether on high yielding varieties or local varieties. Similarly, Gotsch (1971, 1976) argues that large farmers were the first to learn about new technologies because they had better access to extension in research institutions and were able, unlike small farmers, to reach optimum factor combinations by their access to credit. He argues that the diffusion of technology in Pakistan was a source of income disparity, even though the technology itself was perfectly divisible. Similarly, Rochin (1976) in an extensive
 - 58 - study in Pakistan concluded that although adoption rates did not differ by size classes, subsistence farmers had a slightly lagging rate of adoption and used less fertilizer. Small farmers had difficulties in securing supplementary irrigation water. He also noted that slow growth and low use of new technologies have been associated with areas where average size of holdings was small. Small farmers have participated only in the simplest forms of the Green Revolution and remain to an extent unaware of the next, round of improvements in input use. Rochin also shows that a very high proportion of smallholders in rain-fed (barani) areas have adopted the new Mexi-Pak variety of wheat remarkably quickly. He found them to be responsive to innovations and making rapid adjustments when profitable seed varieties were made available to them. Though yield increades were the main reason for adoption, Mexi-Pak also fitted the cropping pattern of the smallholdars easily and did not need extensive changes in farming practices. These adoptions resulted in greater cropping intensities, increased output and increased employment in barani areas. Part of the reason why the evidence on nutrient use is mixed is due to the inappropriate measures of nutrient application used in the studies. Most studies have used nutrient use per total cropped area, which is not the relevant measure: as small farmers have fewer resources they are likely to use scarce inputs like nutrients much more carefully. In order to compensate for the smaller size of their holdings they farm these holdings more inten- sively. As a result the appropriate figure is the fertilizer application per hectare not of the total area cropped but of the area fertilized. There are few data, but when one examines the available evidence presented in Table 4.2, one finds that small farmers use as much and in many cases more nutrients per hectare of area ferti- lized than larger farmers throughout the sub-continent, even in Pakistan. If their yields per cropped hectare are lower, this could either be because, having fewer financial resources, they fertilized a smaller proportion of their areas than larger farmers or because they planted a smaller area with HYVs. This is the reason why the evidence on yields and the adoption of new technologies is often mixed for Pakistan. 1/ 1/ In India at least the evidence contradicts this as small farmers fertilized as much of their area as other farmers,nor do they have a smaller proportion of their area under HYVs0 Perhaps the "access" problem is more serious in Pakistan.

Economic Potential from Nutrient Use In order to estimate the yield potentials for small farmers from more intensive fertilizer use for irrigated and rainfed areas we need to know (i) the percentage of their cultivated areas ferti- lized; (ii) the intensity of fertilization on the area already fertilized; (iii) the yield-responses to nutrient use for at least the major food crops and (iv) the economic profitability of addi- tional nutrient use, given nutrient and output prices. Where such data are available it would be possible to estimate the economic potential (in yield and income terms) of the area not fertil:ized at all (call it P1), as well as the additional or remaining economic potential on the area already fertilized but at levels below the economic optimum, given nutrient and output prices ( call this P2).- If W is the proportion of gross area cultivated that is being fertilized, then the total economic potential (i.e., W1 P1 + (1 - w1) P2 could be estimated for irrigated and rainfed conditions0 The importance of such an exercise arises from the fact that when small farmers' income potentials with respect to nutrient use are assessed it is usually assumed that (i) they use little or no fertilizers; (ii) fertilize small proportions of their total areat (iii) the relevant "yield gaps" are those between zero nutri-ent use (base or control yields) and maximum obtainable yields on the response curves (usually defined in agronomically attainable terms), which are very large; (iv) it would be profitable for small farmers to close these gaps at given nutrient/output prices and (v) finally, that they have the financial means to do so. These assumptions give an unrealistically favorable impression of potential yield increases. To begin with, the data in Table '.2 refute the contention that small farmers use little or no fertilizers, showing that they have already moved some distance along the nutrient-yield response boundaries, and that, at least in India and Pakistan, they use at least as much and in some cases more than medium and large farmers0 In Bangladesh the absolute levels are much lower but again application rates are not significantly different from those on larger farms0 Second, from the available evidence on India shownin T'able 4.3 it is also untrue that small farmers have fertilized only a small proportion of their total areas0 Of course the area fertilized

Irrigation From all that has been said in previous sections, it should be evident that irrigation and controlled water management hold the key to higher productivity increases in the agricultural sector in South Asia. Increased irrigated area is essential to (i) increased yields, because it allows one to shift to higher production functions; (ii) increased cropping intensities, because without controlled water proper management of complex cropping systems is unlikely; (iii) the adoption of high yielding varieties which have been adapted mainly to irrigated conditions; (iv) decreased variations in yields, because it reduces the dependence on weather and monsoons; and (v) increased use of organic and inorganic fertilizers, to which crops are more responsive under irrigated conditions. Generally, there is an inverse relationship between the size of holding and the area under irrigation. (See Tables 4.10 to 4.12.) For example, while nearly 22% of the gross crop area is irrigated on all farms in India, farms of less than 5 acres have 28% - :34% of their area irrigated. This relationship is not so evident in Pakistan. To begin with, a far higher percentage of the tota:L area is irrigated (nearly 74% on all farms)and small farms do not irri- gate a higher percentage (75% - 65 t of the total area is irrigated on small farms). Finally, in Bangladesh a very small percentage of the area is irrigated (6-7%) and there are no substantial differ- ences between farms of various sizes.

 - 78 - Although small farms have a higher proportion of their cjross cropped area irrigated, they do not account for most of the irrigated area in India and Pakistan. In India farms of less than 5 acres account for 22% of the total irrigated area (they account for 19% of the cultivated area); in Pakistan for only 6% (5% of the cultivated area). In Bangladesh the figures are much higher, nearly 50% of the area irrigated (51% of the cultivated area). Further, tl .:e are no significant differences in the sources of irrigation used by dif- ferent sized farms, at least when the evidence available from India is considered (Table 4.13). These aggregate data simply show that small farmers irrigate as much area (if not more,proportionally) as other farmers. They give no clues to the intensity of water use; the timing of the availability of water in farmers'fields; or the efficiency of water use once it gets to the fields0 It is to these issues that the problem of small farmer "access" is normally addressed. The aggregate problem is, what is the unutilized irrigation potential in the sub-continent and to what extent is the increased irrigation going to be available to small farmers? There are two kinds of irrigation to be considered: surface irrigation, mainly through canals, and groundwater irrigation through wells a:nd tubewells. Government studies indicate that there is considerable potential for increased irrigation from both these sources in South Asia (see Table 4.14), conditional upon investment programs that may or may not be undertaken0 Although there is substantial potential for increased irrigation, both from surface and ground- water sources, several factors may prevent small farmers from getting access to it0 With surface irrigation the problems are those of: - lack of investment funds to build farm-level tributaries and proper field-level water courses and drainage systems. Old style irrigation projects that left the development of secon- dary and tertiary systems to local authorities may have unwittingly biased the development of surface irrigation in favor of larger and better-off farmers; - lack of access and control over water flows, to the extent that small farmers are located further down the water distribu- tion network and lack the ability to get canal water released when they need it. Since timing is critical, especially in periods of drought or months of low precipitation, small farmers suffer the most from having to come last in line to receive scarce water resources0 Rationing during periods of scarcity is likely to benefit those who know the local authorities;
