 Another feature of the large and medium size irrigation systems in India has attracted attention. This is the need to upgrade the standards of design and operation of surface schemes to use India's scarce water resources more efficiently. High yielding varieties, because of their greater potential and quicker maturity. ;-e more subject to water stress than traditional varieties. They require more water, and within more narrowly restricted periods0 Host of the irrigation systems built over the last 200 years were designed mainly to deliver relatively small supplements to rainfall over a wide area in order to protect the crops from breaks in the monsoon0 The systems generally lacked controlled structures to deliver water selectively when required by the crops, especially down-field0 Fur- thermore, conveyance utilization efficiencies--the proportion of the water entering the system that is beneficially used--are gen,rally very low0 Recognition of some of these problems has led to a major change in the strategies regarding the development of surface irrigation in India. Most of the earlier financing and schemes were confined to major engineering works, with no funds for associated agricultural development0 In most projects which incorporated work to strengthen agricultural extension services or on-farm developments, these fea- tures were largely ignored in practice0 The lesson learned from these earlier projects was that construction of irrigation infrastructure alone had little agricultural impact0 There was a need to focus more on integration of irrigation and agriculture to achieve better water use and to enable the anticipated benefits from projects to be realized more rapidly. This led in the early 1970s to the idea of command area development (CAD) which comprises the construction of field channels and drains, land levelling and shaping to ensure effective and reliable water supply at the farm level. Some of the larger projects now in- volve 100,000 or more farmers each of whom has to be dealt with individually. Before the actual work of land development can begin, the land records of every farmer must be updated, farm boundaries established, the land surveyed and development plans prepared for loans from land development or commercial banks. As universal par- ticipation is essential, and if a farmer's creditworthiness is in doubt, special arrangements must be made for financing from outside normal credit channels. These are especially necessary for the smaller farmers included in these schemes.
 - 87 - The World Bank's experience with CAD has been mixed. The Rajasthan Canal project, which also included a component for re- organization of extension services, was eminently successful. It is, however, atypical in that it is also a settlement project, and hence involved no problems of land records and credit. In the Chambal projects, in Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh, despite emphasis on organization arrangements, progress with CAD has been pitifully slow for reasons associated with land tenure. Because of the slow progress it was realized that if irrigation development were to continue on a project-by-project basis, a signi- ficant program of on-farm works would never be implemented, particu- larly in view of the estimated backlog of 10 million hectares needing such works. To sj_ed development it was decided to approach the prob- Lem on a state-by-state basis. The solutions to organizational, administrative, financial and legal problems associated with land development were thought to be replicable across states. This is the basis of the approach being taken by such agencies as the Bank today. Apart from the breakthrough on the state-by-state appoach, the ';e:ond major development has been to improve water use through better engineering design and to finance all works except land levelling from budgetary sources, thus bypassing credit institutions and ending the need for clear land titles. The main remaining problems are those associated with cost recovery, either through raising water charges or by passing the budgetary portion to credit institutions for refinancing. To what extent have small farmers benefitted from surface irrigation, CAD or otherwise, in India? Project areas for surface irrigation hitherto have been selected mainly on technical grounds with preference given to low rainfall and drought-prone areas. These areas tend to have larger but very poor farms with considerable potential wh(en irrigated. Traditionally larger farmers, and parti- cularly farmers at the head of a water course, have benefitted most. By bringing water down to each farm and financing this development from budgetary sources rather than by credit, it is expected to ensure small farmer participation. 1/ However, to the extent that surface irrigation requires invest- ment in the development of field channels and to the extent that such investment requires valid and well-known land titles, both 1/ For example, in the recent Orissa Irrigation project, 75% of the projected 30,000 benefitting farm families own less than 5 acres.
 - 88 - small farmers, because they lack the credit, and tenants, because they in addition have no clear title to the land, stand to gain little. The inability of current organizational structures to deliver water from developed irrigation sources to small and tenant farmers is well known. But what organizational reforms are needed to solve these problems is not known. Similarly, enormous problems exist in the development of groundwater potential. The major force in land irrigation develop- ment in India has been private investment in openwells and tubewells. The number of openwells rose from about 3.6 million in 1956 to about 6.1 million in 1971, 1/ and tubewells also proliferated very rapidly in the wake of the new technologies. A private tubewell provicles the cultivator with the command over his irrigation source from which he can water his crops at the right time and with the required quantity--freedom of choice which is of immense value. In India at the end of the Fourth Plan there were some 6.8 million wells in use and about 4.1 million diesel and electric pumps. From the mid-1960s to the early 1970s, this type of investment in irrigation has added more to irrigated area than all the public programs - major, medium and minor - combined. The Government's role in this development has been indirect, mainly through the provision of medium-term credit and rural electrification. 2/ 1/ Report of the National Commission on Agriculture (1976), Part V, Resource Development Government of India Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation, New Delhi, p. 18. 2/ Although not all investments in tubewell development have been financed by institutional credit, estimates of flows of funds through publicly-controlled agricultural credit institutions tend to confirm that private tubewell development accelerated from the mid-1960s to the early 1970s. After that there was a decline and only in recent years has it increased. The decline after 1970-71 did not reflect any shift in public policy. In fact it has been argued that agricultural credit institutions have been further expanded and strengthened since the mid-1960s and subsidies had been eliminated before private tubewell develop- ment reached high rates of growth. The availability of credit for tubewell development has not been a problem, rather it has been the decreased demand for these funds on the part of the farmers, But whether or not credit was a problem for small farmers is not known,
 - 89 - Most of the private tubewell development has so far occurred in regions of India--mostly Punjab, Haryana, Western UP and Tamil Nadu--where conditions were highly favorable for the adoption of the seed-fertilizer-water technology in general and groundwater development in particular. If private tubewell development is to maintain its historical rates,the impetus must now come from other areas The part of India which still has an untapped potential for large scale groundwater development is the Eastern region comprising West Bengal, Orissa, Bihar, Assam and Eastern UP. However, the eco- nomic climaLte and institutional conditions in the Eastern region do not provide as great an economic incentive for investment in tubewells. Agriculturael practices are not highly productive, and are based on traditional varieties of grain, mainly rice. Because existing rice varieties aire not as widely adaptable and broadly pest-resistant as the new wheat varieties, private investment in tubewells may be limited. Eurthermore, as the area has heavier rainfall, the need for irrigation is less obvious and the incremental benefits fewer. Land holdings are much smaller on average so there are fewer farmers for whom even the smallest private tubewell is a viable investment. In addition, the public infrastructure in the Eastern region is not as well developed. The area is not well covered by cooperative or commercial credit institutions, with the result that, while funds for tubewell financing may be available in lines of credit to the state, there are fewer local institutions to channel such funds to small farmers who will use them. Moreover, rural electrification is much less developed in the Eastern region than elsewhere. 1/ A recent innovation in Bihar is the low cost bamboo tubewell which irrigates two to four hectares. A large number of these were sunk in the districts of Purnea and Saharsa and are reported to have given good performance for over four years. These tubewells are operated with mobile diesel pumps, which are available on hire also. For rapid exploitation of groundwater where shallow acquifers exist, these low-cost tubewells hold great promise, but how extensively they can be used is not known. 2/ 1/ At the end of the Fourth Plan, 17% of the villages in the Eastern region including UP had electricity, as compared to 37% in the rest of India and 27% in Northern India. 2/ See Report of the National Commission on Agriculture 1976, Part V, Government of India, Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation, New Delhi, 1976.
 - 90 Electric pumping sets are generally trouble-free, and cheap and easy to operate, but due to the low voltage in many areas of I:ndi they have not been used as effectively as -hey might. D_ , I have an advantage in that they can be conveniently moved from one tubewell to another, thus saving capital costs. But the operatir. cost per hour of diesel tubewells is nearly double that of electricua operated ones. The critical problem here is that access to electrici v for farm use has also been disproportionately in favor of the largei farmers. Pakistan has similar problems. It has had irrigation systems for centuries. Irrigation development in Pakistan has been dominated by large infrastructure projects designed to transfer water from the Western rivers to the Eastern rivers. These projects have used up the limited funds for over a decade. More recently there has been development of on-farm work,in particular improvements of water courses to improve water-course delivery efficiency5, so that farmers located at the tail end of water courses, generally the smaller farmers, receive more reliable water supply. In Bangladesh, prior to independence in 1971, the major emphasis was on large-scale flood control and gravity irrigation projects. These were costly and were a poor allocation of scarce resources. Since independence there has been a shift from development of heavy infrastructure to simple, low cost, quick-yielding minor irrigation projects. The main emphasis in these newer projects is on low lift pumps and tubewells. Bangladesh is an exception in that it has pioneered different organizational forms in irrigation and to a considerable degree its groundwater has been reaching smaller farmers. Given the small size of most holdings in Bangladesh, organization of farmer groups was a necessity for the optimum use of minor irrigation facilities, typi- cally covering 10 to 50 acres. Although in Bangladesh there are few large farmers the relatively "better off" farmers tend to initiate the formation of such groups and dominate their operations. Evidence from the I.DoA. Northwest Tubewells project suggests this clearly, though it also shows that small farmers have benefitted significantly. To some extent domination of irrigation systems by larger, better off farmers is inevitable, since these farmers "dominate the loca:L eco- nomy, are the means of credit to the poorer sections, have some education, have political influence with good connections at the Union or Thana level and know how to pull strings to get things done:' 1/ 1/ Per Arne Stroberg, "Bangladesh: Water Devleopment, Organizational Aspects of Tubewell Irrigation Projects:, (mimeo), 1977.
 - 91 - In recent projects increasing emphasis has been placed on reaching small farmers. In the Shallow Tubewells project, for a farmer's group to be eligible for credit, "at least one-half of the proposed irrigated area must belong to farmers whose total holdings are less than three acres each." 1/ It is hoped that by ensuring the parti- cipation ol small farms on a more equitable basis these projects will help in arresting their gradually worsening economic status. It would be unrealistic, however, to expect them, even if fully successful, significantly to narrow the existing inequality among various segments of the rural society or to solve the problems of access to increased irrigation by small farmers. Finally, the relationship between credit and access to ground- water sources is well established. Because of scale economies, tubewells are accessible to smallholders only if they purchase them as a group. The Thana Irrigation Program in Bangladesh is the only example of this sort of activity. The TIP begins with the formation of a pump group which is encouraged to act as a cooperative, and can expect to obtain credit to purchase tubewells. But Blair (1974) has shown while a large proportion of the groups do become cooperatives, only a small proportion of the members receive any loans. Possibly a few men take advantage of the program by padding their membership lists with non-existent group members. At least some of the groups are composed of farmers in a quasi-tenant debt relationship to the group manager. Further, because credit payments are made on the basis of area irrigated, farmers have no incentive to use water carefully. Though farmers are expected to assume all operating costs of the pumps for a 5-year period, until recently their opera- tions were subsidized; moreover, the distribution of pumps has become "a distribution of favors." Alam (1975) in looking at the deep tubewell irrigation schemes in Bangladesh, found that the level of utilization of deep tubewells was positively related to the availability of cooperative credit and other inputs. The deep tubewells were rented to coop groups by the Bangladesh Agricultural Development Cooperation. While membership of the coop,erative groups came from all farm sizes, leadership rested mainly with the medium and large farmers. Due to the fragmentation of ownership holdings and lack of cohesiveness in the pump jroup, the small farmers were not able to benefit. Myers (1972) quoting a study by iAli Khan (1971) of a similar cooperative group trying to take advantage of tubewell irrigation, found that 24% of the coopera- tive members received 62% of the loans. The larger landholders had greater indebtedness,and the larger the loan, the greater was the percentage of loan default. He found that the proportion of loans taken by management committee members (larger farmers!) was dispro- portionate---managers were 36% of the loanees and received 65% of the loans. 1/ World Bank internal memorandum.
 - 92 - To conclude, although irrigation water is essential to increase small fanner productivityp and although the potential for expanding irrigation is substantial, aevere problems remain in assuming that small farmers will (get &a larger share of this increase than in the past. New organisational forms being designed to increase small farmer access to both surface and groundwater irrigation are still in their infancy, and their success is far from assured0
 - 93 - Chapter V: INSTITUTIONAL CONSTRAINTS: PROBLEMS OF ACCESS TO FACTOR AND PRODUCT MARKETS There is a widespread feeling that small farmers would have benefitted to a far greater extent from the new technologies had they had better access to factor and product markets for essential inputs. There are several areas in which small farmer access prob- lems have been termed acute. The most important of these is credit. A. Credit for Small Farmers Credit is a key element in the modernization of agriculture and has been treated as such for most small farmer development programs around the world. 1/ Indeed, in some projects, among them IDA loans to India and Pakistan, credit is the major focus. From the preceding discussion it is evident that increased use of purchased inputs will be necessary for small farmers. What role does credit play, and to what extent is it a constraint for small farmers? When we examine credit systems in South Asia, we observe that small farmers (i) need credit more often; (ii) get less of it, at least from institutional sources; (iii) usually as a result pay more for it and (iv) find it a considerable constraint on their ability to increase farm incomes further. The most salient feature of the credit system in South Asia is that institutional loans provide only a very small percentage of total agricultural credit to the farming systems: non-institutional sources provide 70% - 90% of all loans in the agricultural sector. The "coverage" of the institutional sector is also low--only 5 - 20% of all farmers receive institutional loans (Table 5.1). Most of the institutional loans come from public sources (100% in Bangladesh and Pakistan), while most of the non-institutional credit is "non- commercial"--i.e., the rates and repayment terms are not clearly known and are a matter of private arrangement. When profitable opportunities for investment appear, private sources of credit tend to concentrate, but usually at interest rates so high as to discourage small farmers frc,m borrowing. Public and institutional sources then become essential and partly displace private funds. Notwithstanding the sufficiency of private sources of credit to finance some form of small farmer progress, it is important for institutional credit to provide funds in order to compete with the system and break the monopoly power of private lenders. Public credit is needed in this case, not.to promote small farmer adoption, but to help with the transformation of the rural economy. This brings us to the traditional villains of the piece in Emall farmer credit--the moneylenders. The private moneylenders are often characterized as exploiters , monopolists , extor- tionists and the like, but they are still the most important source of rural credit. Attempts to drive out or at least to compete with non-institutional sources of credit, principally for example by lowering interest rates, have not been particularly successful. Interest Rates and Interest Subsidies A pure comparison of interest rates is not appropriate. Bottomly (1963a, 1963b, 1964a, 1964b, 1973) has argued consistently that rural rates of interest have several component parts: the pure interest rate; the administrative premium; the risk premium; and the monopoly profit. He has argued that from the point of view of the borrower, pure interest rates differ little between institutional and non-institutional sources0 On the other hand, the administrative premium and the risk premium in credit to small farmers is much higher0 Although some amount of monopoly profit remains, this monopo:Ly profit is far less than has normally been argued0 He has further shown that blanket attempts by governments to finance the status quo at low rates of interest will not succeed0 What is actually needed is a change in technology and a substantial reduction in risk premiums0 He has shown that it actually takes an increase in the demand for productive loanable funds brought about by new technologies to effect a lower rate of interest0 (Bottomly, 1973)o Are interest rates too high for small farmers? The evidience seems to suggest the opposite if small farmers can borrow at the rates they do without serious defaults0 Should aaricultural credit be subsidized, especially in the institutional sector? A major finding of the AID small farmer credit review, on the contrary, was that if institutional interest rates were raised from, say, the average current rate of 5% to 20%, there would be few losses in terms of program goals and some major gains for small farmers0 1/ The traditional view in this regard is that small farmers especially need subsidized credit and low interest rates0 This argument of course rests on the view that farmers are sensitive to changes in interest rates and that low rates are necessary to induce them to use credit for productive investments. This position must now be challenged from the evidence available. Small farmers have been willing to invest when profitable 1/ See especially the papers by Adams (1973), Claudio Gonzalez Vega (1973), Millard Long (1973), P0E. Church (1973), ToFo Carroll and IoJ. It follows that the case for low interest rates is unacceptable, except insofar as they promote borrowers' welfare.l/ Artificially low interest rates have other problems. They do not cover operating expenses and result in portfolio losses for credit institutions, and they are unable to cover the cost of tech- nical supervision. Several authors have pointed out that low interest rates jeopardize the financial integrity of credit institutions and that they also encourage credit institutions to minimize losses by concentrating on the more reliable, prosperous farmer, particularly those with collateral. Thus, the bulk of the small farm sector is excluded. This case has been effectively argued by Adams (1972 and 1973) who has stated that low interest rate policies offered to small farmers are a great hoax and that they do small farmers more harm than good. He insists that the rationalization of interest rates is one of the most important policy reforms countries could under- take in the field of small farmer finance. Further, he has argued and evidence is available to show that financial savings may be generated in the rural sector at rates much greater than commonly thought, if interest rates were much higher. 2/ But to encourage 1/ There is often a distinction between the welfare or equity objectives and the efficiency of production objectives in credit programs. No one can deny that credit programs are often set up for welfare objectives. Further, governments have a right to establish welfare objectives. No one can say that consumption credit is not justified or that credit pro- grams are not a convenient way of transferring income. The real problem occurs with regard to the conflict between pro- duction and welfare objectives within the same 2rogram. This conflict often creates problems both for the effectiveness of the program and for evaluating their success. Credit at low interest rates in welfare or consumption credit type programs must be seen as an income transfer. 2/ For evidence from the Republic of China, see Adams, Ong and Singh (1975). Rural banks and provincial branch banks offer such facilities. The ability of agriculture to generate much of its own capital requirements is so importalnt, in the long run, that governments should encourage credit insiti- tutions which offer the savings facilities. The arguments against raising i?terest rates stem first f:rom the fact that the input and output commodity markets in which small farmers operate often suffer from monopoly and other dis- tortions, and their economic efficiency is unlikely to be improved simply by correction of interest rates. Second, it is argued that institutions must charge much lower rates than moneylenders because the latter offer many more services; third, that the hypothesized effect of high interest rates on the supply of commercial credit and rural savings is still untested except in a few countries; and finally, that governments, politicians, farmers and others support low interest rates and, right or wrong, their views are not likely to be easily overcome. Subsidiw for small farmers can be justified on several grounds, but it is a mistake to use the credit mechanism as a vehicle for subsidy. The argument against subsidizing small farmers by dealing gently with delinquency is that this permissiveness destroys the discipline which is vital to institutional viability. There are three reasons for subsidizing small farmers: (i) to redistribute income to them from other sectors; (ii) to maintain subsisterLce levels among extremely poor farmers, especially those with such poor resources that improved access or even new technology would not make their farms viable; (iii) to encourage production on potentially viable farms, to encourage them to adopt new tech- nologies. These are legitimate reasons, but it has been arguied that the subsidy should be incorporated in the price of services and supplies rather than in the price of credit. This is because subsidizing credit distorts credit markets, leads to opportunity costs way below what they truly are, and leads to large farmers borrowing funds to invest in virtually useless enterprises. However, subsidies to credit institutions do play a useful role in covering institutional deficits, at least in the initial stages.
 - 109 - Credit and Risk It is evident that risk is a significant factor in small farmer decision-making, and creditors recognize this clearly. It is well recognized that even the most illiterate farmers place some probabilities on the outcome of their farming decisions, and on future events outside their own experience. 1/ Since they live at the margin of subsistence, they cannot accept risks which might jeppardize their family survival. There is ample evidence to indicate that increased farm investments will take place only when risks are removed from the minds of farmers. 2/ Small farmers face a number of risks which can significantly affect the extent to which they adopt new technologies and the extent to which credit use becomes productive: - Yield risk is probably the most serious risk faced by small farmers. The new technologies consistently show greater yield variations than do traditional methods. Und,er adverse weather conditions where irrigation and controlled water use are not available, the high yielding varieties sometimes yield even less than the traditional varieties. Under ideal conditions of course the yields are often four to five times higher. There is an obvious need to develop varieties which show less yield variability, even at the expense of some reduction in average yields. It iis a well known fact that farmers in South Asia,in conditions of uncertain rainfall, keep a higher percentage of t:heir crop area under drought-resistant crops or grow crop mixtures. 3/ Further, farmers must also consider the uncertainties of floods, insects, disease and even wars, all of which might adversely affect the yields obtatined in any given year. crop insurance programs hold some promise for spreading the weather risks faced by farmers, but these must be applied with great care. The more successful credit programs normally provide many technical packages to overcome local differences in yields. - Price variability of inputs or products is also of concern to the farmer. Input and product prices are exogenous factors which fluctuate from year to year, yet the farmer 1/ See Wharton (1972), Roumasset (1976) and Anderson and Dillon (1977). 7/ Naidu (1964). 3/ Malya and Rajagopalam (1964).
 - 110 must predict specific values for each crop before th(e crop season. Kahlon and Johl (1964) found that in the Indian Punjab farmers varied acreages according to price and yield variations, and that a risk fund was used to meet the expected risks, the fund growing in size with the use of new technologies. Government price guaran- tees may help; price policies are also subject to change even during the crop year, but they directly affect the profitability of new technoloqies and are especiallv needed for small farmers who are highly risk-averse. The most successful credit programs have been supported by price policies which reduce the input and product price variability to the farmer. Credit Institutions Finally there are several "institutional factors" that present problems of access to credit (or other inputs) for small farmers. The most difficult to handle is the power structure in rural socie- ties,that is so rigged against small farmer interests that credit (or other) program objectives are likely to be frustrated,unless the government is prepared to challenge that rural power. Gotsch (1973) has made this point repeatedly and convincingly for Pakistan. Another issue that seems to emerge is whether it is better to establish special new institutions for small farmers (for example the Small and Marginal Farmer Development Agencies in India) or to reorient the existing financial structure to serve small farmer needs. The evidence shows that the institutional form seems to matter less than economic factors, especially those of technology and farm-level profitability. 1/ An institutional problem, however, that is of some interest is how one can handle a large number of small farmer clients and do it cheaply. This capability depends upon administrative skills, low- cost delivery, supervision and collection methods and access to a large supply of funds. It is found that decentralized agencies are better in this regard. Private cooperatives especially have some outstanding features (which include local participation, group sanctions against delinquency and multiplication of scarce technical training). Cooperatives play a substantial role in providing small farmer credit in South Asiai but face two severe problems: the shortage of local managerial expertise and the existing rural power structure. Although cooperative movements 1/ See E.B. Rice (1973), op. cit., Bose (1974), Schluter (1973), Stepanek (1973), Solaiman and Haq (1973) and Tinnermeir and Dowsell (1973).
 - ill - have been extensively used especially in Bangladesh, the common outcome is for the cooperative to be taken over by the establishment and the small farmer interest to be partly or completely abandoned. In the typical class-structured rural societies of South Asia, cooperatives are a viLbl_ for small farmer progress only if governments are committed to them. Another proposal for reaching larger numbers of small farmers is to let iprivate moneylenders continue to meet small farmer needs, as they have in the past. The advantages of the moneylender in- clude his low overhead and other administrative costs and a personal familiarity with clients that can substantially reduce the rate of default. rhe disadvantages include the predictable tendency of these informal lenders to concentrate on the progressive small farmers. The problem of giving additional power to those rural classes is that the concentration of economic power in rural Asian societies needs to be reduced. Although informal lending sources will be around for a long time, it is useful for conventional credit institutions to imitate their success by using their positive features. Since credit programs by definition imply redistribution of economic and poli- tical opportunity, they cannot succeed without confronting existing rural power. B. Marketing Problems Small farmers have only a small surplus to market. This very condition of "subsistence production" means that they need to resort to output markets less frequently. Farm management studies in India have shown that nearly 80-90% of total farm production on farms less than 5 acres is kept for home consumption. 1/ Nonethe- less, the evidence is clear that small farmers are welf integrated into the local product and labor markets. The so-called "subsis- tence farmer syndrome" where small farmers are isolated from local factor and product markets and live "in subsistence and self- sufficiency" just does not exist in South Asia. 2/ 1/ See Studies in the Economics of Farm Management carried out in various districts by Directorate of Economics and Statistics, Ministry of Food and Agriculture,Delhi. 2/ See Lele (1971).

All farmers may suffer from being tied to particular marketing channels due to credit or other service obligations. Market effectiveness despends critically on infrastructure and information, and the lack of these makes rural markets inefficient and costly for all farnmers. The small farnier's special handicap is his lack of credit or cash income with which to buy non-farm inputs, as well as his small marketable surplus. But the problem may be much larger than that: although their marketable surplus is small, they do not necessarily sell small amounts of their output in markets--their marketed sur- lus is actually large. I/ Farm management and other studies show that small farmers sell output in the post-harvest season only to purchase the same commodities in the later pre-harvest months. This means that although they may need to consume nearly all the food they produce, they sell in the post-harvest months to meet their cash obligations, only to purchase their food needs lacter, normally at higher prices and usually with credit to tide them over into the next post harvest period. 2/ Thus, they sell cheap and buy dear. So do other farmers but to a lesser degree. Some of the solutions involve expanded on-farm storage faci- lities, better support prices, an elimination of hoarding by middlemen, improved access to institutional credit, and finally the insurance of crops. Each of these solutions is equally important for other farmers as well. But what about the vaunted inefficiency of traditional marketing systems and the concern that small farmers are often victims of a special "marketing connection"? The villains of the "marketing connection" are middlemen and so called petty traders, which all governments in South Asia have castigated as exploiters and hoarders . What little evidence we have on the working of market- ing systems in South Asia does not support this image, at least in India. 3/ 1/ Marketable surplus is the difference between total annual household consumption and farm output of a given commodlity and can be negative if consumption exceeds sales. Traditional marketing systems in subsistence agriculture typically suffer from inadequate transport and storage facilities, lack of stan- dardization in weights and measures, poor dissemination of market- ing information, a large number of intermediaries, and inadequate finance for trading. Although "strong bargaining positions" are enjoyed by some traders, profits are usually limited by the large number of intermediaries. The high profits earned by afew traders are due to their large scale of operations or their command over capital--a scarce resource-- and these earnings are not monopolistic. Further, traders are relatively skillful, and well informed about prices and demand through their local contacts even though they lack good informa- tion on overall stocks and supply conditions. Second, if not, what other opportunities for increasing income (and employment) can be found to supplement incomes from land? The answers to these questions depend upon the size of the holding considered. It is useful to consider three broad groups: - the near landless, farmers with less than one acre (0.5 ha.) of land. For this group of farmers the present land holdings are too small to provide an adequate standard of living. Further, even if their present farm incomes were doubled (i.e. more than a doubling of yields - a range that is beyond the 60%- 80% maximum potential income increases to be expected in either irrigated or unirrigated conditions, even assuming zero levels of nutrient use at present) their per capita incomes would remain well below subsistence levels. 2/ Therefore they will have to rely mainly on wage iIncomes from on-farm employment and improvements in incomes from non-farm activities.  - 133 - C. Wage Employment in Rural Areas and the Landless What scope does rural wage employment provide for expanding employment opportunities for the landless? An analysis of all the issues involved is beyond the scope of the present paper, but a few points are worth summarizing: - Although a variety of often conflicting estimates are given in various studies, the fact is that we do not know for sure how many landless there are in South Asia. All we know is that their numbers are large. The best aggregate estimates we can assemble were given in Table 1.3, but we need to note that in all cases these are likely to be too low. This is particularly true for Pakistan. - There are two sources of growth in rural employment:(i) the growth in the on-farm demand for wage labor and (ii) the growth in non-farm employment, especially in processing, marketing, trans- portation, repair and other services and input and consumer good distribution systems. As noted above, both these sources of growth are "agriculturally led". The relationship between the growth of farm output and demand for wage labor largely depends on the size distributior, of holdings, the cropping patterns and, most critically, on farm technologies. Where agricultural growth has been rapid, as in the two Punjabs, a lot of the potential stimulus to employment has been offset by farm mechanization. 1/ Increased irrigation and cropping intensities will definitely increase demand for farm labor (although changes from persian tubewell irrigation may not), but how much of this demand will be met by family as distinct from wage labor is not certain. Attempts must be made to ensure that rapid agricultural growth is not accompanied by a decline in the labor intensities of agricultural production,especially where there is surplus labor. But this is not a simple issue. - The growth of non-farm employment depends upon linkages within rural areas as well as linkages with the other (industry and export) sectors. Although the importance of these rural linkages, and agriculture-industry interactions has been repeat- edly emphasized 2/ as possible means for increased employment 1/ The literature on these issues itself is vast and needs a more careful treatment than is given here. 2/ See especially Mellor (1976), Mellor and Lele (1973) for rural linkages and Johnston and Kilby (1975) for agriculture-industry interactions.
 - 134 - opportunities in rural areas, little empirical work has been clone to quantify first the linkages and second their employment impact0 The anecdotal evidence and the little empirical evidence we have a1l seem to suggest a high correlation between the rates of agri- cultural growth and employment generation in rural areas. But the evidence is mainly from areas where high rates of agricultura'L growth have prevailed over considerable periods - East Punjab, Republic of China, Republic of Korea, Malaysia. All this seems to suggest that unless agricultural grouth exceeds an annual rate of 3.5 - 4%, and that unless such a rate is sustained for at Least a decade, these linkage effects will remain small and are not likely to contribute much to the solution of the rural employment problem - at least in a context where a high proportion of the rural popu- lation is unemployed or underemployed, and the numbers of rural unemployed are growing at rates exceedinq 2 percent per annum. So a high and sustained rate of agricultural growth is a necessary and sufficient condition for high rates of growth of non-farm employment opportunities. These problems will never be solved if agriculture is stagnant. - The experience with rural work programs as a means for providing employment in South Asia has been mixed. 1/ Although they serve a very useful purpose in the relief of sudden disasters, the salient fact is that they have had only an insignificant impact on the magnitude of the rural unemployment problem, except in very few cases and in a limited regional context. 2/ In South Asia, whatever the organizational, productivity, implementation andl fiscal problems associated with the development of rural work programs, the sheer maqnitnlde of the task will continue to defeat their purpose, if this purpose is to make substantial inroads into rural unemployment.  - 162 - ANNEX III RURAL WORKS PROGRAMS IN SOUTH ASIA In view of (i) the large numbers of unemployed and underewTmloyed in the rural areas of South Asia, (ii) the low overall elasticities of on-farm and off-farm employment relative to (tit) tho still extensive additions to the rural labor force expected in the decade ahead, we have to arrive at the conclusion that mere growth, at least at rates expe- rienced in the past or expected in the future and of the type experienced in the past, will not solve the problem of rural unemployment. Indeed, in the decades ahead even accelerated and optiEistic agricultural growth rates will be associated with positive unemployMent growth in rural areas. Therefore, a case for short-run relief to the unemployed becomes unassail- able. As Raj Krishna (1973) has pointed out: "A society which has failed to reduce the unemployment problem in two decades of development cannot ask its unemployed to wait indefinitely for the utterly uncertain prospect of employment growth catching up with population growth or income growth." (p. 18) It is in this context that one needs to ask to what extent large scale public works programs can be effective in creating new sources of employment in rural areas, while at the same time constructing assets for increased economic growth. A. Past Experience with Public Works ProArams in South Asia There has been considerable use of public works programs in South Asia, and their experience has been entensively studied. 1/ These include three programs in Bangladesh--(i) the Works Program (WP), (ii) the Thana Irrigation Program (TIP) and (iii) the IntQgrated Rural Development Program (IRDP)--two programs in Pakistan--(i) the Rural Works Program (RWP), and (ii) the Peoples Works Program (PWP)=-ead three programs in India --(i) the Scarcity Relief Program (SRP), (ii) the Creeh Scheme for Rural Emplayment (CSRE) and (lii) the Drought Prone Areas Program (DPAP). Although the literature on this subject is extensive and greiftg, the detailed study done by the Bank provides the most useful review 2/ and its conclusions 1/ For a detailed review see S.J. The find- ings of the Bank Study show that: (:L) Although the programs have generally been geared to provide employment to specific target groups-the "rural poor", the "most needy", "poor surplus agricultural labor"'these groups were not the only ones which were included. (2) Although all these programs contained elements of long-term employment and infrastructure development they were primarily disaster relief or income augmenting in nature. They were not designed either to solve the rural unemployment problem or to create rural assets effectively and efficiently. Their success in these latter categories was limited. They have been planned and implemented in isolation and not as part of a broader strategy either to create new rural assets or to attack the fundamentals of the unemployment problem. Indeed the physical, budgetary and political constraints inherent (at conception) in these programs make it impossible for them alone to employ all those without jobs or to provide supple- mental seasonal incomes to all those who need them. (3) As instruments for creating large-scale employment opportuni- ties in rural areas these programs were far from effective. The Bangladesh WP provided only 29 million days of employment annually which works out to an average of 1.5 days per member of the labor force annually. Similarly, figures calculated by the study for the annual average work days generated per member of the labor force are 0.2 for India's DPAP and 0.3 for Pakistan's RWP. Even for India's Crash Scheme for Rural Employment which provided some 178 million man days of employ- ment in total, the figure is low--one man day per member of the labor force (Table 2). Even if one were to accept a very low estimate of only 10% of the rural labor force unemployed (or underemployed), these figures suggest that these programs provided only between 10-15 days <anxtum) of -mannually per unemployed in rural areas.  - 169 - and tertiary benefits depend on the types of works carried out. Directly productive projects (irrigation, drainage, soil conservation) have the greatest impact on future production and thus the highest potential for creating additional demudnd for labor; but by and large their benefits visibly accrue to those who own land or assets that are improved, and in proportion to their ownership. Thus, where land distribution is bimodal as in Pakistan the secondary benefits are regressive in nature as they accentuate the in- equity inherent in the ownership of rural assets; on the other hand where the land distribution is more even, as in Bangladesh, the secondary benefits may be more evenly shared among landowners; however, the only benefits to the landless are those from wages. An illustrative case analyzed for Bangladesh showed that the returns to land (and hence land- owners) reclaimed by public works projects are five times higher than the returns to labor. 1/ It is of course possible that some smallholders are among those receiving employment (and hence in the target group) but still the relative rural income distribution may not improve much if increased employ- ment is all that accrues to target groups at which these programs are aimed. The benefits from irrigation and drainage projects are likely to be even more skewed. Projects that emphasize economic infrastructure (roads, reforestation, markets) tend to have the best redis- trtbutive effects in the short run, as they are usually located on public land. But again longer term benefits will accrue to farmers (in proportion to the size of their holdings and more importantly in relation to their marketable surplus) and perhaps to traders and intermediaries providing farm inputs or buying farm outputs. Perhaps increasing labor mobility and opening remtote areas may assist the landless to move to areas of better employment opportunities. Social infrastructure projects (schools, clinics, low-cost housing) can providean opportunity for improving the social welfare of a broad range of the population. However, actual benefits depend on who has access to the facilities. Here the rural power structure probably prevents these benefits from having a broad gauge effect. To assure that benefits accrue to smallholders and the landless may be feasible only where the land distribution is unimodal or where small farmers are geographically separated. But in South Asia where small and large holdings are physically adjacent it will normally be impossible to direct most of the longer term benefits to small farmers or the landless. (9) Most of the public works programs in South Asia have been subject to political influence on both their original design as well as in the course of implementation. The two most important factors in bringing about what Burki, et.al. call program mutations are (i) political objectives and commitments of the regimes under- taking the programs, which are rarely articulated, and (ii) the action of local elites who are in a good position to alter the nature of ptublic works programs to serve their own interests. There are several decision points at which these pressures for mutation are applied.and these include (i) the choice of projects, (ii) the choice oi technology, especially its labor intensity, (iii) the choice of project implementation agent, (iv) the establishment of wage rates, (v) the selection of employees and 'vi) the location of the project. Pressures at all these points may work to transfer benefits from target groups to other intermediate, usually higher income, groups. This has been particularly true in Pakistan where the skewed distribution of land assets and political power has assured a more rapid program mutation. In the PWP and RWP, political loyalty rather than project performance became the basis for public works allocations. "Large land owners, rural contractors and small town tradesmen quickly shaped the program to serve their own interests" by shifting the decisions from the lowest level Union Councils to the much larger District Councils controlled by these interests. The work was given to contractors with a rapid decline in labor intensity and employ- ment creation. 1/ As the programs were not backed by political commitment to serve the poor, they deepened the cynicism on part of the tenants, landless and other unemployed. In Bangladesh, the more egalitarian rural structure slowed the process of mutation so that the emergence of power brokers and the reversal of broad participation in project deci- sions and benefits took considerable time. But the greater freedom for local governing bodies to make decisions and to implement programs within a framework carefully structured by the government has been one of the factors leading to greater success of the WP in Bangladesh. Before one reaches any conclusions about rural works programs, it is useful to review the experience of the most recent effort in this direction--the Maharashtra Employment Guarantee Scheme (MEGS). 1/ J.W. Thomas (1971), op.cit., p. 306.

The Scheme was begun by Maharashtra's State Government in 1972 and consists of a guarantee of employment to the rural poor including small and - marginal farmers, landless agricultural workers and rural artisans. In a country as large as India with pervasive conditions of unemployment and underemployment in rural areas, a program that sets out to guarantee employnent to its citizens is of enormous interest. The Scheme aims to provide "gainful and productive employment-- gainful to the individual and productive to the economy--to all unskilled persons in rural areas who need work and are prepared to do manual labor but cannot find work on their own." Although the. scheme was begun in 1972, it was engulfed by the large relief operations Launched to handle the 1972/74 drought. Therefore the Scheme did not come into operation until 1974/75. The main features of-the Scheme are as follows: (1) the beneficiaries of the guarantee have no choice as to the type of work on which they will be employed: (2) the guarantees are given at the district level, i.e., guarantees are given that work is provided within a radius of 5 kilometers of a village where the laborers have registFed. (It is-not certain whether one can repeatedly register for work once it has been obtained for 30 days, but presumably this is so.); (5) works are undertaken departmentally and not through contractors. At least 60% of the expenditures must be for wages to laborers.  - 180 - These are: , (1) Rural public works programs can be designed and administered on a large scale with the primary objective of reducing long-term rural unemployment. Further,if this is seen as their main goal they can have a significant impact on long-term employment prospects in rural areas. (2) Such programs if properly financed need not be inflationary and can even serve as a means for urban-rural transfers. (3) Such programs cannot succeed without the political commitment to this employment creation goal at the highest levels. The MEGS :is a bold acknowledgment of both the citizen's right to work as well as of the nature of the crisis that exists in the countryside. The State's long history of rural works program and the more recent successful management of the Scarcity Relief Works on a large scale during the severe droughts in 1973-74 are partly responsible for the enlivened attitudes and adminis- trative commitments, but at the core the MEGS is a political commitment to a strategy of rural development with a focus on rural employment and rural asset creation designed to alleviate poverty. The only comparable effort has been in the massive works programs carried out in the rural areas of China. To do this on a statuary basis through a democrat:ic and legislative process, by passing the Employw2nt Guarantee Bill, is a measure of this intensive commitment. Without this commitment the MEGS would not have succeeded even to the extent that it has. The MEGS is also viewed by some as a social contract between the state and the citizen wherein the issues of labor dignity, choice of work, group participation and design and responsibility for timely execution of public works are included. It can also be seen as a way of organizing rural labor over the whole State. Some feel that the opportunity the MEGS provides to organize labor on a massive scale in rural areas is its salient feature while others have seen it as a first stop towardo the unionization of rural labor. Even earlier schemes had been designed to improve soil conservatioii in the State. This program had followed the denudation of Maharashtra's forest land which led to erosion. This degradation of agricultural land over at least half the State,compounded by the spread of cultivation on to marginal lands, are important causes for the State's poor past agricultuiral performance. Soil conservation programs were mainly concenitrated on the formation of field bunds. These ran into several problems. Since most farmers have small plots of land distributed around the village, and records of field' bunding for land under one village were often kept in the books of two or more units, illiterate farmers were often charged more than one pavment in a single year. In the absence of land consolidation and in the context of an illiterate peasantry, the require- ments of contour bunding were not very successful. Few farmers had fields which were large enough to accommodate contour bunds without the formation of small awkward triangles in the corners of the fields. Finally, the maintenance of field bunds has been generally poor, because there has been no concomitant improvement in crop husbandry that might produce quick and evident results. Thus, only an integrated program of land consolidation, introduction of rapid technological change, with HYVs and improved crop practices tied to a program of irrigation and water development,makes any sense. The means for accomplishing these ends lie partly with the rural works program. Thus, reducing unemployment, increasing farm productivity and efficiency and increasing the intensity of land use are all comple- mentary elements in any scheme for attacking rural poverty. Maharashtra's experience with the MEGS may be the first real chance to attempt such an integrated approach. The stakes are too high not to attempt what is possible. The question arises whether the MEGS can be replicated elsewhere and whether national employment guarantee schemes can be undertaken. Any decision on the replication of MEGS on a national scale would be premature until: (1) Maharashtra has had a chance to use a guarantee of employment to strengthen local decision making in management and (2) until the need to move the scheme into the center of development administration is recog- nized. CONCLUSIONS Although Maharashtra's EGS, if instituted on a nationwide basis, provides a glimmer of hope in partially alleviating the problems of unemployment in South Asia, one cannot be too sanguine about the abiLlity of rural public works programs to solve the long-term problems of unem- ployment. Their cause is structural--too large a growth in the labor fo9Cz) eoAhc2 with too slow a growth in the demand for labor in rural areas. Rural-urban migration is not a solution, for it only displaces the problem from the countryside to the cities. Semi-permanent labor mobilization in rural areas on a scale that has been matched only by the Pharoahs in Egypt and Mao in China, can and must be part of the answer. The experience with rural work programs as a means for providing employment in South Asia has been mixed. doc.repnme: Small farmers and the landless in South Asia
doc.abstracts: The majority of the world's poor are among the 625 million people who reside in the rural areas of Bangladesh, India and Pakistan. The rural poor consist predominantly of: (i) small owner and tenant cultivators with operational holdings of less than 5 acres (2 hectares); and (ii) the landless. There are approximately 83 million households with a population of 410 million in these categories. This paper attempts to examine the prospects for improved livelihood for these households and the problems faced by them in the three major countries of South Asia. Improving the livelihood of small cultivators depends, in the absence of any major programs of land redistribution, upon improving their productivity. The availability of abundant family labor and cash scarcity suggests an initial concentration on labor-intensive methods to raise small farmer productivity through improved cultural practices. Further increases in productivity require multiple cropping, increased use of inputs--water, nutrients, pesticides--and the adoption of high-yielding varieties (HYVs). The paper examines both the prospects and the problems involved in pursuing these strategies.
